## {#tools data-menu-title="Financial Tools"}

[Fishers need financial tools to protect income variability]{.slide-title}

<hr>

- Fishers are risk averse in income [@Bockstael1983; @Eggert2004;@Brick2012;@Holland2008]

  - They would prefer more stable income, over flucutations

  
- Current finanicial tools are limited for fishers [@Mumford2009;@Kaperski2013;@Sethi2010]


- Call for new financial tools to build more resilient Blue Economies [@Sumaila2021;@Watson2023]

##  {#ibi-why data-menu-title="Index Based Insurance"}

[Why Index Insurance?]{.slide-title}

<hr>

-   **Avoids quantifying individual loss**

    -   Very difficult to indemnify whether a fisher lost income due to weather or their own luck
    
  <br>

-   **Fast payouts and cheap administration**

    -   Money in policyholders accounts in as little as 3 days

<br>

-   **Index Insurance immune to "chasing the trigger" moral hazard**

    -   Fishers choosing to fish less will not lead to excessive payouts for the insurance company

    -   Fishers cannot control sea surface temperature

## {#why-not data-menu-title="Why not"}

[Why is there no index insurance market in fisheries?]{.slide-title}

<hr>


::: {.callout-note icon="false"  style="font-size: 1.5em;"}
## Basis Risk Definition:

Policyholders not receiving insurance payouts when they suffer a loss
:::

- Basis risk lowers demand for products [@Clarke2016]

  - Greatest impediment to uptake in agriculture [@binswanger2012;@Jensen2018]
  
::: {.incremental}
  
- Indices that are tightly correlated with fish catch are needed  

- Environmental variables influence catch, but really difficult to measure

  - Non-linear, unobservables, management plays a role
  
:::

## {#br-math data-menu-title="Basis Risk"}

[What is Basis Risk?]{.slide-title}

<hr>

- Fisher catch is a function of weather and other unobserved factors

$$
y=f(B(\tilde{w}))+ \epsilon
$${#eq-prod}


::::{.columns}

:::{.column}

:::{.body-text-s}
$y$ harvest

$\tilde{w}$ weather index

$B(\cdot)$ function mapping weather to fishery productivity

:::

:::

:::{.column}

:::{.body-text-s}
$\epsilon$ random unobserved factors

$f(\cdot)$ function mapping productivity to harvest

:::

:::

::::


::: fragment
:::{.center-text} 
**To create an index, we need a model to estimate** $f(B(\tilde{w}))$
:::

:::

## {#br-var data-menu-title="Basis Risk"}

[Basis Risk is the combined model error and unexplained variance]{.slide-title}

<hr>

$$
y=g(\tilde{w})+\eta+\epsilon
$${#eq-g}

::::{.columns}

:::{.column}

:::{.body-text-s}
$g(\tilde{w})$ Prediction Model


:::

:::

:::{.column}

:::{.body-text-s}


$\eta$  Random model error

:::

:::

::::

<br>

::: {.incremental}

- Goal is to minimize $\eta + \epsilon$

- More weather variables may reduce $\epsilon$

- Better models may reduce $\eta$

:::



## {#contract data-menu-title="Contract"}

[Use our estimator as an index compared to a critical value]{.slide-title}

<hr>

- Weather signal $w$ observed


$$
I(w)=\overbrace{\max(c\mathbb{E}[y]-\hat{y}(w),0)}^{\text{Payout if model predicts less than average catch}}
$${#eq-pay}

::::{.columns}

:::{.column}

:::{.body-text-s}

$I(w)$ Insurance payout

$c$ Coverage level

:::

:::

:::{.column}

:::{.body-text-s}
$\mathbb{E}[y]$ Long run average catch

$\hat{y}(w)$ Model prediction

:::

:::

::::


## {#premium data-menu-title="Premium"}

[Fishers have to pay a premium]{.slide-title}

<hr>


- Insurance company charges a premium, $\rho$

$$
\rho=\mathbb{E}[I(w)]m
$${#eq-prem}

::::{.columns}

:::{.column}

:::{.body-text-s}

 $\mathbb{E}[I(w)]$ Average payout 

:::

:::

:::{.column}

:::{.body-text-s}
$m$ premium loading factor (how much does an insurer charge to make a profit)

:::

:::

::::


::: fragment

:::{.center-text}
**Example**
:::

*We observe a SST of 15$^{\circ}$C. Our model predicts a catch of 80 metric tons, the long run average catch is 100 metric tons. Insurance will pay the equivalent of 20 metric tons. Fishers have to pay a small premium  equivlalent to 5 metric tons each year*
:::

## {#ut data-menu-title="Utility"}

[Measure utility to see if fishers are better off with insurance ]{.slide-title}

<hr>

::: {.callout-note icon="false"  style="font-size: 1.5em;"}
## Utility Definition:

Measure of how desirable something is. Includes our perception and tolerance for risk. 

People prefer a sure thing over a lottery

:::


:::{.center-text}

**Demand:** Compare the improvement as a percent increase in utility

:::

$$
u_{rr}=\frac{u_i-u_{ni}}{u_{ni}}
$$

## {#mrkt data-menu-title="Market"}

[Find the "market" price: $m^*$]{.slide-title}

<hr>

Fishers will be indifferent between insurance and no insurance when $u_{rr}=0$

The $m^*$ that makes $u_{rr}=0$ is the highest an insurance company could charge and still have fishers buy the contract

::::{.columns}

:::{.column}

$$
u_{ni}(y)=u_{i}(y,I(\omega),\rho)
$$

:::

:::{.column}
Reminder:
$\rho=\mathbb{E}[I(w)]m$

:::

::::
  
  - The selected $m^*$ is the marginal willingness to pay for insurance
  
  - High $m^*$ means fishers really want insurance
  
  - $m^*<1$, insurance has to be subsidized
  
- Loss Ratio: $\frac{\sum I(w)}{\sum \rho}<1$, then insurance is profitable for insurance company at $m^*$

## {#rolling data-menu-title="Rolling Forecast"}

[Advantages of validation strategy]{.slide-title}

<hr>

- Assess model performance in true out-of-sample setting

  - Calculate $u_{rr}$ for each year in test set
  
- Mimics how insurance would be offered in practice

  - Update model each year with new data

- Tune hyperparameters on the average RMSE in the test set

  - Limited data availability (n=34), can't afford to drop more data

## {#lm data-menu-title="Linear Models"}

[Linear Models are the gold standard in agriculture insurance]{.slide-title}

<hr>

- $\beta_1$ captures the yield/weather dependence

$$
y_t=\beta_0+\beta_1w_t+\epsilon_t
$$

- Easy interpretation:

**Fishers receive $\beta_1$ dollars for every one degree sea surface temperature rises above 16$^{\circ}$, **


## {#lasso data-menu-title="Lasso"}

[Lasso Regression: Data driven shrinkage]{.slide-title}

<hr>

$$
\hat{\beta}^{lasso}=\arg\min_{\beta}\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_i-\beta_0-\sum_{j=1}^{p}w_{ij}\beta_j)^2+\lambda\sum_{j=1}^{p}|\beta_j|\right\}
$$ {#eq-lasso}

```{r}
#| tbl-align: center

load(here::here("data","output","squid_cara10-1.rda"))

library(kableExtra)

las<-models |> filter(pred_mod=='lasso') |> select(mods)
a<-las[1]
b<-a$mods[[1]][[1]][[2]][,33] 

round(b,2)|> broom::tidy() |> knitr::kable(col.names=c("Variables","Coefficient Estimates")) |> 
  kable_paper() |> 
  scroll_box(width="900px",height="400px") |> 
  column_spec(2, bold=ifelse(b==0,TRUE,FALSE),background=ifelse(b==0,"lightblue","white"))
```

## {#disc-1 data-menu-title="Discussion"}

[Fisheries Index Insurance is feasible]{.slide-title}

<hr>

- We must account for the non-linear interactions between catch and weather due to the Ecosystem nature of fisheries

- Machine Learning models can capture these complex relationships and reduce basis risk

  - Their flexibility is what makes them so useful
  
  - Need to be cautious of overfitting
  
  - Data leakage in the premium

## {#vars data-menu-title="Calculation of Weather Variables"}

[How each variable is calculated]{.slide-title}

<hr>

:::{.center}
[Back to Data slide](#data){.btn .btn-outline-primary .btn role="button"}
:::

**Sea Surface Temperature:** Yearly Average from NOAA Marine heat wave (MHW) readings ats 5x5 km resolution aggregated and weighted by fishing block

**Habitat Compression Index:** Cummulative scores of monthly area of cold water below average temperature thresholds along the US West Coast. 

**BEUTI:** Monthly average of BEUTI Index in the spring months of March, April, and May from @Jacox2018

**CUTI:** Monthly average of CUTI Index in the spring months of March, April, and May from @Jacox2018

**Spring Transition Index:** First day of the year when cummulative sum of BEUTI reaches minimum value [@Suca2022]

**Relaxtion:** Count of the number of days when CUTI exceeds 1.0 $m^2s^{-1}$ followed by three or more consecutive days of CUTI <0.5 $m^2s^{-1}$.

**Frequency:** Proportion of days when CUTI is between 0.5 and 2.0 $m^2s^{-1}$

**El Nino:** Average of MEI.v2 index

**PDO:** Average of PDO ERSST V5

**ONI** The 3 month rolling average of ERSST v5 SST in the Nino 3.4 Region. Use January, February, and March measure.

**Krill Abundance:** Log catch per unit effort using a delta-generalized linear model from Rockfish Recruitment and Ecoystem Assessment Survey

**Paralarvae Abundance:** Log catch per unit effort using a delta-generalized linear model from Rockfish Recruitment and Ecoystem Assessment Survey
